sections.1_story: Imagine you have a flat piece of paper with shapes drawn on it. If you fold it along the lines, it forms a 3D object like a cube or a box. Net folding questions test your ability to visualize how a 2D net folds into a 3D shape.
2_definitions: ğŸ’¡ Net: A two-dimensional pattern that can be folded to form a three-dimensional solid.
ğŸ’¡ Folding: The process of bending the net along the lines to create a 3D object.
ğŸ’¡ Face: A flat surface of a 3D object.
ğŸ’¡ Edge: The line where two faces meet.
ğŸ’¡ Vertex: The point where three or more edges meet.
ğŸ’¡ Adjacent Faces: Faces that share a common edge.
ğŸ’¡ Opposite Faces: Faces that do not touch each other in the folded solid.
ğŸ’¡ Cube Net: A net that can be folded to form a cube.
ğŸ’¡ Invalid Net: A net that cannot be folded to form the required 3D shape.
ğŸ’¡ Visualization: The mental process of imagining the folding of the net.
3_formula_bank: ğŸ§® 1. Count the number of faces in the net and match with the 3D shape.
ğŸ§® 2. Check if all faces are connected properly.
ğŸ§® 3. Visualize folding each face up to form the solid.
ğŸ§® 4. Ensure no faces overlap or are left out.
ğŸ§® 5. For cubes, opposite faces must not be adjacent in the net.
ğŸ§® 6. Trace the path from one face to another to check adjacency.
ğŸ§® 7. Use elimination to rule out impossible nets.
ğŸ§® 8. Practice with paper models to improve visualization.
ğŸ§® 9. Mark faces with symbols to track their positions.
ğŸ§® 10. Remember that a cube has 6 faces, 12 edges, and 8 vertices.
ğŸ§® 11. For other solids, match the net to the number of faces, edges, and vertices.
ğŸ§® 12. Check for symmetry in the net.
ğŸ§® 13. Use arrows or numbers to help track folding.
ğŸ§® 14. Practice with different types of nets (cube, cuboid, pyramid, etc.).
ğŸ§® 15. Review previous year questions for common net patterns.
4_micro_examples: A net with 6 squares folds into a cube.
A net with 4 triangles forms a tetrahedron.
A net with 1 rectangle and 2 squares forms a cuboid.
A net with 5 squares and 1 rectangle forms a box.
A net with 3 rectangles and 2 squares forms a prism.
A net with 6 triangles forms an octahedron.
A net with 1 square and 4 triangles forms a pyramid.
A net with 2 hexagons and 6 rectangles forms a hexagonal prism.
A net with 8 triangles forms an octahedron.
A net with 12 pentagons forms a dodecahedron.

5_exam_examples.problem: Which of the following nets will form a cube?
solution_steps: Count the number of faces (should be 6).
Check if all faces are squares.
Visualize folding each face up.
Ensure no faces overlap or are left out.
5_exam_examples.answer: The net with 6 connected squares in a T-shape will form a cube.

5_exam_examples.problem: A net has 4 triangles. What solid will it form?
solution_steps: Count the number of faces (4).
Check the shape of each face (triangle).
Visualize folding the triangles together.
Confirm if all faces meet at vertices.

5_exam_examples.problem: Which net cannot form a cube?
solution_steps: Check if any faces overlap when folded.
Check if all faces are connected.
Visualize the folding process.
Eliminate nets with adjacent opposite faces.
5_exam_examples.answer: The net with two squares separated by more than one face cannot form a cube.

5_exam_examples.problem: A net has 1 square and 4 triangles. What solid will it form?
solution_steps: Identify the base (square).
Visualize folding each triangle up from the sides.
Check if all triangles meet at a point.
Confirm the solid is closed.
5_exam_examples.answer: It will form a square pyramid.

5_exam_examples.problem: Which net will form a cuboid?
solution_steps: Count the number of faces (should be 6).
Check if opposite faces are equal rectangles.
Visualize folding the net.
Ensure all faces are connected.
5_exam_examples.answer: The net with 3 pairs of equal rectangles will form a cuboid.
